results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 01
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie introduces a packed program. Tim Danko curates at Westspace “Paper Skin - Constructed Guts” an exhibition of the work of thirty contemporary local and overseas comic book producers/artists. Brendan Tolley, Kirrily Schell and Cassandra Tytler are a few of the artists. Nat & Ali provide more comic relief with their lived-in performance on opening night. At Linden St Kilda Contemporary Arts is ‘High Tide’, a photographic exhibition by contemporary indigenous artists looking at the landscape. Curated by Christian Thompson the artists include; Destiny Deacon, Brenda Croft, Michael Riley, Jenny Fraser, Jason Hampton and Dianne Jones. An excerpt of Michael Riley’s film ‘Empire’ is included with music by Anthony Parthos performed by the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra (first screened on ABC 2000). At Ian Potter Museum of Art ‘It’s a Beautiful Day’ opens. An exhibition exploring the gamut of contemporary painting that includes the work of Peter Booth, Brent Harris, Vivien Shark le Wit, Anne Wallace and David Jolly to name a few. Curated by Bala Starr.

results.title: Makin pitchas
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description: Makin Pitchas is a compilation of four short films made by young Kooris who are a part of the Ballarat and District Aboriginal Cooperative (BADAC). The project was an initiative funded by VicHealth to encourage young Kooris to explore and articulate their experiences of mental health issues, most particularly family issues, grief, conflict, racism and bullying. The final product is intended to promote discussion of mental health issues among young people in Indigenous communities as well as acting as a tool for cross cultural education in mainstream organisations. “Believe in Yourself” (dir. Tim Stares) is the story of Dave, a koori youth who feels alienated and discouraged by his parents who would prefer he drop out of school and lay bricks for his father rather than follow his dream to be a filmmaker. “A World of Colour” (dir. Myles Walsh) focuses on a mediation session, after a basketball game turns into a racial slagging match. “Goodnight Irene” (dir. Tim Stares) tells the story of Ruth, a young girl who has to do a history project about family’s pastimes. Unfortunately she cannot report anything to her teacher because the memories her mother has of her past are too painful to discuss. In “Verandah Dreaming” (dir. Myles Walsh) Verna loses her husband in the war and her son to drugs. Hope seems further lost when her grandson is sent to prison for stealing a car. However, with the help of the Aboriginal Legal Service, Sammy joins an Aboriginal Dance group and finds direction to his life.

results.title: Sorry book: Kutcha; Larry (A) [Reconciliation advertisements]
results.brief_description: These two short community advertisements (30 seconds each) were made to create awareness about the suffering of indigenous peoples as a result of forced removal from their families in the middle of twentieth century Australia. The audience is asked to consider the current impact experienced by these people today as a direct result of government policy whilst the Aboriginal people are still asking “why?”. Sign the “Sorry book” at www.apology.west.net.au.

results.title: Shimmer in the city
results.creator_credit: Amanda Hickey and Special Broadcasting Service Corporation
results.brief_description: A detailed look at urban Aboriginal art through interviews with artists, national and international curators, art dealers and art critics, and their views on the place of the work in relation to traditional Aboriginal art as well as Australian society at large. The notion of preconceived ideas of Aboriginal art is discussed as well as the non-stereotypical aboriginality represented in the urban artist’s work where mythical, cultural and environmental heritage is referred to, but situated politically as a confrontation of past and present issues effecting indigenous Australians. Through the interviews with the artists and critics of their work the autobiographical nature of the art is evoked, underlining both the personal and broad social relevance of the art to contemporary Aboriginal experience. It is thorough documentary on the broad spectrum of work being produced that also raises the key issues of Aboriginal ownership of imagery and the question of Aboriginal copyright.

results.title: Darwin's body snatchers
results.creator_credit: Chris Oxley, Channel 4, U K and Laurel Productions
results.brief_description: This program looks at the export trade in Aboriginal skeletons, skulls and body parts rife during the nineteenth century and which continued up until 1940. Anthropologists and museums influenced by the work of Charles Darwin sought these remains for scientific study and museum exhibition. Australian doctors, scientists and supposedly respectable citizens may have colluded in both grave robbing and “killing to order”, to fulfil the European demand for the supply of Aboriginal bodies, which were treated as commodities. The program looks at shifts in museum policy and the efforts by groups such as the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre to have these remains repatriated from overseas institutions back to Australia for proper burial by their descendants.

results.title: Telephones: using and abusing
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, E Brereton and Post Office Film Unit
results.brief_description: A dramatised account promoting speedy and efficient use of the telephone. Guides us in the correct methods of dialling, answering and speaking on the telephone. With animation explains the complex sequence of operations within an automatic exchange when a call is made.

results.title: The Loved ones [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Kate Hampel, Angela Borelli, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Victoria and Taxi Films
results.brief_description: A documentary film that provides an insight into the running of the Lort Smith Animal Hospital in North Melbourne, Victoria. Established in the 1930s, the Lort Smith is a well-known, well-respected Melbourne icon recognised for its wonderful service in the treatment of sick animals - its mission being that no sick animal will ever be turned away. However by the 1990s the hospital building, run-down and outdated, was reaching a crisis point. Its clients had risen to an almost unmanageable level, the budget was in deficit to a million dollars annually and staffing issues were becoming a major headache. Radical change was needed if the Lort Smith was to continue. In 1998, through Managing Director Dr Alan Lawther and his efforts, the Lort Smith Management Committee approved plans for the building of a new hospital. The next step was to raise the finance. Dr Lawther’s push for change extended to a more corporate and professional concept of fund-raising than had been practised in the past and also a rethinking on staff performance and salaries. The documentary features interviews with Dr Lawther, his staff and the Management Committee as well as an inside observation of clients and their pets and the hospital generally. NB: Some scenes may be considered distressing.

results.title: Aboriginal dreaming stories
results.brief_description: Jointly presented by Francis Firebrace Jones and Paulin Mcleod, these stories are presented with great enthusiasm and in the spirit of enhancing respect for the land and the Aboriginal people of Australia. The story titles are: In the beginning ; Creation of day and night ; Who discovered Australia? ; How fire came to Earth ; Giant Goanna and the Little black snake ; Why does the kookaburra laugh ; Old bush turkey ; Sharing time ; How the kangaroo got its pouch ; The Platypus ; Death of a cockatoo ; Walkabout ; The Bunyip ; “the Wallagara Man.

results.title: Manyu-Wana 1
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This program contains the following topics: Magic; number 3; working as a stockman; reading of “The Man and the tree”; number 1; blowing noses; letter “M”; making hairstring; words for ‘wide’ and ‘narrow’; car magic; bat and ball magic. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.
